intro: Ptelea trifoliata var. confinis, commonly known as the western ninebark, is a deciduous shrub native to the western United States. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are typically three-lobed, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, white to pinkish flowers in clusters during the spring, followed by small, red berries in the fall. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodland and streamside habitats. Its adaptability and ornamental value make it a popular choice for landscaping in suitable climates.
